Steel maker Nucor (NUE) was also down 3% after offering preliminary Q4 earnings guidance below consensus views.Solar electrical components and systems maker First Solar (FSLR) surged to the top of the S&P 500 with an 8% advance. Frontier Communications (FTR) was next in line with a 5% gain.More than 20% of the Nasdaq 100 stocks opened higher. Cognizant (CTSH) ran ahead, rising nearly 3%.On the IBD 50 list, 40 stocks opened higher and a third of the group rose more than 1%.Gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC) bounced 3% higher, taking back a portion of Tuesday's 10% tumble. The gain put shares 16% above a 19.07 buy point.Refiner Tesoro (TSO) climbed almost 3% in strong trade. The stock is working on a third straight advance as it rebounds from a test of support at its 200-day moving average. The stock had dropped 7% below a 105.64 buy point after briefly clearing that buy marker in a cup-with-handle base. Investors may have opted to trip the 7% to 8% sell rule. Shares are now less than 1% from retaking the buy point.Global Payments (GPN) trimmed some losses, but remained down 8% in heavy trade. The Atlanta-based payment processing outfit announced it would pay $4.3 billion to acquire peer Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). Global also reported slightly better than expected fiscal Q2 earnings and revenue growth of 5% — below analyst consensus forecasts. Heartland shares surged 11%, listing shares to a new high.

Investors' fears around rising interest rates may apparently trump decent results from homebuilders, as Monday's preliminary, partial results from Toll Bros. (TOL) for the quarter ended Oct. 31 showed. The luxury homebuilder said that its revenue grew 6% from a year earlier to $1.437 billion, slightly above the $1.434 billion that analysts had expected, according to a poll by Thomson…

After losing ground on Monday, shares of No. 1 homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) roared back to life Tuesday after it reported better-than-expected sales and earnings for its September-ending fourth quarter as the number of finished homes climbed 23% and new orders rose 19%, led by strong growth in the Southeast.Shares closed up 8.3% in the stock market today. They had dipped more than 2% Monday along with a broad falloff in homebuilder stocks as investors weighed the increased possibility of a Fed rate hike in December. Other homebuilders also sprung back on Tuesday.The Fort Worth, Texas-based D.R. Horton earned 64 cents a share in the quarter, two cents above views and up from last year's 45 cents. Homebuilding revenue of $3.05 billion was 28% higher than a year earlier.Smaller homebuilder Beazer Homes (BZH), which also reported results for its September-ending quarter early Tuesday, didn't fare as well early in the trading day after it reported mixed results, including a 12% gain in home closings vs. a year earlier but a slight drop in orders and homebuilding gross margin. But it ended the day up 5.6%.Of Beazer's $354.5 million in net income from continuing operations, nearly $324 million came from a tax benefit. The company said that it expects "significant" growth in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in 2016 and beyond, however.While D.R. Horton's net sales orders — a future-looking barometer — increased 19% to 8,477 homes, the value of those homes rose 22% to $2.5 billion. The biggest gains were in the Southeast, where the number of communities had grown sharply over the last couple of years.Orders in the Southeast jumped 40% to 2,868 homes. Orders in the South Central region, which includes the firm's home state of Texas, rose nearly 8% to 2,367 homes, but their value increased 19%.Horton's average selling prices in the quarter were up only 3.4% as sales of lower-priced, entry-level Express Homes increased. With an average price of $191,000, they accounted for more than 20% of homes sold and 14% of home-sales revenue, the majority of sales coming from Texas, Florida and the Carolinas, said a company spokeswoman.In a conference call, executives said that they expect Express Homes and the firm's high-end Emerald Homes division to continue expanding, with Express Homes seen rising to around 20% of home-sales revenue by the end of fiscal 2016 and Emerald Homes in the high single digits.At the end of September, Horton had a sales order backlog of 10,662 homes, up 10% in value from a year earlier and a "well-stocked supply of land and lots," Chief Executive David Auld said in a morning conference call. That, he added, gives it a "strong competitive advantage."Horton raised its quarterly dividend 28% to 8 cents a share, payable on Dec. 14.Lennar (LEN), the second largest homebuilder, was up 3.35% at the close Tuesday. PulteGroup (PHM) gained 3.6%. Toll Bros. (TOL) advanced 2%. It fell 1.2% Monday even though it reported a fairly decent October-ending quarter that day.Follow Marilyn Alva on Twitter @IBD_MAlva.

Whether you're looking to buy a new home or an existing one this spring, you'll likely find much the same thing just about everywhere: high demand, low supply, rising prices and heavy competition. That's the prognosis of U.S. housing experts as the spring homebuying season moves into its high gear. In most sections of the country, the combination of pent-up…

Housing surprised to the upside for a change — and in a big way. April starts surged more than 20% to the highest since November 2007, and permits leapt 10% to the fastest since 2008. Both single-family and multifamily starts jumped by double-digits in the month, but single-family starts are up 15% vs. a year ago.Starts in the weather-battered Northeast offered some proof of the temporary factors that have been wreaking havoc with economic data in past months. They tumbled 57% from January to February, then rebounded 115% in March and 86% in April.Homebuilders have had a mixed spring. D.R. Horton (DHI) said orders jumped by nearly a third in Q1, but that margins could be pressured as entry-level homes make up a greater share of the total. Meritage (MTH) is forecasting revenue that's higher by as much as 25-20% in 2015, but PulteGroup (PHM) saw profit drop 26% in Q1. Builder confidence took a step back in April, the National Association of Home Builders said Monday, but sentiment remains relatively high, with builders particularly bullish about the next 6 months.Lennar (LEN), PulteGroup, KB Home (KBH), Meritage and D.R. Horton (DHI) rallied in the stock market today, but came off earlier highs as the market reversed.
U.S. residential loan originations rose sharply in the first quarter, amid housing market hopes that more potential homebuyers would be sealing deals.
But the sharp increase during the quarter was driven by refinance originations, while purchase loan originations were up only slightly.
Loan originations for single-family homes and condos rose 17% from a year earlier to 1,551,865 loans, though they were down 6% from the prior quarter, according to a report from RealtyTrac Thursday.
The dollar volume of Q1 loan originations was up 32% from a year ago, to $377 billion, but down 1% from Q4, the report noted.
Refinance originations represented nearly $256 billion in Q1, or 67.8% of all loan origination dollar volume. Purchase loan originations represented $121 billion, or 32.2%.
As a share of total loan origination dollar volume, purchase originations reached a recent peak of 49.2% in Q2 2014, followed by three quarters of decreasing share.

"A dip in interest rates early in the year combined with lowered mortgage insurance premiums for FHA loans breathed some life back into the refinancing market in the first quarter," said Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac, in a statement.

"The purchase loan market remained largely missing in action, despite tepid growth from a year ago," he added. "The prime buying season still remains ahead, providing some hope that first-time homebuyers and other traditional buyers relying on traditional financing will come out of the woodwork in greater numbers in the coming months."

As more first-time and traditional buyers move off the sidelines, it could aid builders who target some sales to first-time buyers.KB Home (KBH), Lennar (LEN), Meritage Homes (MTH) and PulteGroup (PHM) all build for several market segments.
Rising refi originations can bring homeowners funds for home improvement, good for stores Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's Cos. (LOW)

Of the nearly 1.6 million loan originations in Q1, 471,822 were purchase loan originations, down 25% from the prior quarter and up less than 1% from a year ago. U.S. existing-home prices rose 7.4% in Q1 vs. a year earlier, the third straight quarter of faster appreciation but below 2013's double-digit gains, the National Association of Realtors reported Monday. The median existing single-family home prices rose in 85% of U.S. major metro markets (148 out of 174) based on closings in Q1 vs. a year earlier. Fifty-one metro areas…

Vacation-home demand has been on a steady climb as a strong stock market, low interest rates and tempting deals have prompted high-end households to spend more freely on second residences and summer getaways.
The push comes as more high-net-worth buyers have opted to put some of the earnings they've gained from a rising stock market into second homes in spots that support a more leisure lifestyle.
Contributing to the increased demand are baby boomers home shopping for a place to vacation now, and retire to later.
Real estate brokers in resort locales from Massachusetts' Cape Cod to Nevada's Lake Tahoe report brisk second-home buying activity during the year's first quarter.
And real estate experts say the vacation home market is heating up.
"It's a very good time for vacation homes," Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac told IBD. "They're a hot commodity now."
The reasons? Home prices are still "undervalued" in a lot areas, which are still coming back from the recession, he adds, citing parts of Florida as an example.
Deals From Coast To Desert

Blomquist says other areas where buyers can find some good deals are parts of New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Nevada, where foreclosures are still rising. They include vacation-home spots like Cape Cod and Las Vegas.

"The common thread (on the buying side) is this recovery is really benefiting people, who were conservative and careful with money during the last housing bubble and now have to ability to buy in a market with much tighter lending standards," Blomquist adds. "This recovery is about buyers with an investor mindset and with cash. Those people are willing to extend their real estate investment with a vacation home."
Adds Morningstar analyst James Krapfel: "Conditions are favorable for more second-home demand.

"More baby boomers are aging into their retirement years and we've had fairly strong equity markets. Also, the prices of their primary homes have gone up significantly in the past couple of years, which gives them more confidence to invest in a second home."
The trend bodes well for homebuilders such as Toll Bros. (TOL), PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN), which build homes in various vacation and resort spots.

Nationwide, sales of homes intended for vacation use surged 57.4% last year to an estimated 1.13 million properties, according to the National Association of Realtors investment-and vacation-home buyers survey. It was the highest amount since NAR began the survey in 2003.
Vacation-home sales accounted for 21% of all transactions in 2014, their highest market share since the survey was first conducted.

Jessica Lautz, director of survey research and communications for the NAR, says one driver of the increase is the strong growth in the stock market last year, which has allowed buyers to take some of the gains they earned and invest in a vacation home.
Another driver is the fact that baby boomers are nearing retirement and one in five of vacation-property buyers surveyed plan to live in their homes when they retire.
Where Is Demand Strong?

Luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. builds homes in a number of vacation and resort areas. It has a big presence in Florida, where it builds homes in cities such as Orlando, Naples and Palm Beach, says Frederick Cooper, senior vice president of finance. It also builds homes in locales such as metro Denver in Colorado; Phoenix and Scottsdale in Arizona; and Reno and Las Vegas in Nevada.

"Over the past couple of years, but very much this year we've seen strong demand in the markets where people buy vacation homes, with particular strength in the Denver area, Florida and Reno this year," Cooper told IBD.

In some cases the robust demand is being driven by demographics where baby boomers want to have two homes, he adds, and in some other cases it's being driven by the strength in the stock market and "the solid position of the affluent customer."
He says prices vary from market to market. But in markets where there is "solid demand there is pricing power."

Out West, the Tahoe market has had a "very busy and exciting first quarter, and the second quarter is starting off strong," said Pamela Francis, a real estate broker at Century 21 At Tahoe Paradise, by email.
She says most of the buyers are purchasing second homes.
Average home prices in South Lake Tahoe are up 4% since this time last year.
In the Northeast, Steve Clay, a real estate broker and team leader at Keller Williams Realty covering Upper Cape Cod, is also upbeat about the climate for vacation home buying.
After an "awful winter" with record snow fall, business really picked up in mid-to-late March, says Clay.
"And it hasn't let up since," he adds. "I think we're experiencing a general market improvement and also some pent-up demand created by an unusually harsh winter."
He anticipates a "good season" for vacation home sales.
"A lot of it is due to an improved economy and improving job market," he adds.
At the end of the first quarter, his team had 24 properties under contract vs. 18 last year.
He says most agents at his firm say second homes are the biggest part of their business.
Allan Dechert, co-owner of Ferguson Dechert Real Estate in Avalon, N.J., is also upbeat about the vacation-home market in the Stone Harbor and Avalon beach areas.
"I'm optimistic this year will be a great year," he told IBD.
Second-home sales activity was "pretty steady" in 2014 and into the year's fourth quarter, he says.

So far this year — despite the harsh winter weather — the activity through the first quarter was "really good," Dechert said. This year's first quarter was "significantly above" last year's for his team in dollars and in units.
He says purchases have been priced across the board. In March, for example, sale prices ranged from $460,000 to $2.5 million.

Overall, the total sales inventory on Stone Harbor and Avalon, is down 20% from a year ago, Dechert says, adding that things are "tightening up" with fewer properties on the market, which means pricing will go up.
Arizona's Experience
Kris Anderson, team leader for Your Premier Team at Re/Max Excalibur in Scottsdale, Ariz., is also seeing some pickup in vacation home buying activity.
In the first quarter, 15.2% of all sales in Arizona's Maricopa County — which includes Phoenix — were for vacation homes, up from 9% in the 2014 fourth quarter, she told IBD.
In the first quarter of 2015, vacation home sales for the county were up 1% from a year earlier.
Another indication that activity is up in the county: Pending home sales under contract were up 7% from a year earlier in the first quarter and the median sales price increased by 5.5%.

Vacation homes made up 15% of total pending sales, the same percentage as last year, Anderson said, adding, "that's not a great percentage, but we're happy with 15%."Vacation-home demand has been on a steady climb as a strong stock market, low interest rates and tempting deals have prompted high-end households to spend more freely on second residences and summer getaways.The push comes as more high-net-worth buyers have opted to put some of the earnings they've gained from a rising stock market into second homes in spots that support a more leisure lifestyle.Contributing to the increased demand are baby boomers home shopping for a place to vacation now, and retire to later.Real estate brokers in resort locales from Massachusetts' Cape Cod to Nevada's Lake Tahoe report brisk second-home buying activity during the year's first quarter.And real estate experts say the vacation home market is heating up."It's a very good time for vacation homes," Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac told IBD. "They're a hot commodity now."The reasons? Home prices are still "undervalued" in a lot areas, which are still coming back from the recession, he adds, citing parts of Florida as an example.Deals From Coast To DesertBlomquist says other areas where buyers can find some good deals are parts of New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Nevada, where foreclosures are still rising. They include vacation-home spots like Cape Cod and Las Vegas."The common thread (on the buying side) is this recovery is really benefiting people, who were conservative and careful with money during the last housing bubble and now have to ability to buy in a market with much tighter lending standards," Blomquist adds. GDP growth tumbles GDP grew at an annual rate of 0.2% in the government's Q1 initial read. That was below even the sharply reduced consensus forecast of 1%. Exports slumped 7.2% in Q1, likely thanks to a stronger dollar. Consumer spending rose 1.9%, less than half the 4.4% gain in Q4. Government spending — federal, state and local — declined…

Your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: What you need to know as an investor for the coming day, as earnings season gets into full swing. Southwest Airlines (LUV) and other carriers have earnings on tap, as…

Stocks were mixed in afternoon trading Tuesday despite better-than-expected June housing data. Netflix (NFLX) and Super Micro Computer (SMCI) were hit especially hard.The Nasdaq composite fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average was essentially flat in the stock market today. Volume was mixed, rising 9% on the Nasdaq and declining a fraction on the NYSE compared to the same time Monday.Computer hardware, steel and entertainment stocks led on the downside, while shipping and defense stocks rose.Super Micro Computer, a maker of computer server systems and components, plunged 28% to its lowest level in more than two years. The drop came after Super Micro Computer late Monday slashed its fiscal Q4 sales and earnings outlook.Netflix tumbled nearly 14% after much weaker-than-expected subscriber growth trumped better-than-expected Q2 profit. Netflix's shares are 36% below their 52-week high. The stock has been consolidating since December.Lockheed Martin (LMT) rose as much as 3% to a new high after the defense major posted a 12% gain in Q2 profit to $3.28 a share on an 11% rise in revenue to $12.91 billion. Both figures beat Wall Street forecasts. But Lockheed stock reversed lower to dip into the red. That could be related to conference call concerns about cash usage on plane constructionLockheed Martin, maker of the F-35 fighter jet, also raised its 2016 outlook. The stock is still in the 5% buy zone from 245.47 entry of a flat base.In economic news, the Commerce Department said housing starts rose almost 5% in June, to an annualized rate of 1.189 million, above forecasts for 1.17 million. However, May figures were revised lower.Building permits, a guide to future activity, rose more than 1% to an annualized rate of 1.153 million, above expectations for 1.15 million.However, most leading building stocks were lower. Shares of D.R. Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and Lennar (LEN) each posted small losses. So did LGI Homes (LGIH).D.R. Horton and Pulte Group report earnings this week.

Stocks opened with minor losses Tuesday, despite a strong read on June housing activity.Dow industrials fell 0.1% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq eased 0.2%.Some big earnings reports rolled out late Monday and early Tuesday, led by Netflix (NFLX), Goldman Sachs (GS), IBM (IBM) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).The stock market is so far enjoying a healthy July. The Nasdaq is up 4.4% for the month through Monday, its best performance since October. The S&P 500's 3.2% gain is its strongest since March. Among small caps, the Russell 2000 has a 4.9% gain for the month -- also its best since March. If the market pauses or pulls back, however, a few telling factors could clue in investors to where institutional investors might be headed next.The Commerce Department said June housing starts rose almost 5%, to an annualized rate of 1.189 million vs. a 1.135 million tally for May that was revised downward.  Economists had projected a rate of 1.17 million.Building permits, a guide to future activity, rose more than 1% to 1.153 million on an annualized basis. Consensus had forecast permits issued at a pace of 1.15 million.The reaction among homebuilding stocks was muted. Pulte Homes (PHM) rose 0.2% at the open. Toll Brothers (TOL) added 0.7%.  Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and LGI Homes (LGIH) posted small gains. Pulte and D.R. Horton report results on Thursday.Netflix opened with a 13% loss after second-quarter subscriber growth of 1.68 million fell far short of the company's 2.5 million new-subscriber target. Earnings growth blew past analyst expectations, while revenue met estimates. Netflix shares have been consolidating since December.Goldman Sachs slipped 0.5% at the open after reporting second-quarter earnings, and revenue fell less than projected.IBM edged up 0.5% after reporting upside second-quarter results late Monday, aided by a 30% gain in cloud-based revenue.Johnson & Johnson rose 1% after beating analysts' second-quarter earnings and revenue forecasts, as well as raising its full-year guidance above consensus views.VMware (VMW) spiked 8% at the open after strong second-quarter results.Super Micro Computer (SMCI) toppled 26%. The server system and computer components manufacturer after management sharply reduced its fiscal fourth quarter sales and earnings guidance late Monday.Auto parts retailer Genuine Parts (GPC) dropped 3% at the open. The Atlanta-based chain reported Q2 sales and earnings below analyst targets, and guided full-year earnigns to the low end of the consensus range.Oil traded up and down, with West Texas Intermediate futures just above $45.50 a barrel. Gold inched up a fraction to above $1,331 an ounce. The dollar gained vs. the euro, yen and pound. Bonds ticked higher, trimming the 10-year Treasury yield 2 basis points to 1.56%.Overseas, China's markets took modest losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 jumped 1.4% as Japan's market reopened after a three-day holiday.In Europe, stocks were off their morning lows in afternoon traded. London's FTSE 100 had flattened. The CAC 40 in Paris was down 0.7% and Germany's DAX trimmed to a 0.9% loss.

Shares caved 7.7% to 20.03 in the stock market today, a fall likely compounded by the 11.4 % drop…

Sales of new homes came in at an annual pace of 481,000 units in March — hardly the 518,000 that economists had been expecting. That represented an 11.4% drop from February. But there were some important caveats. February's read of 543,000 newly constructed homes sold was a seven-year high, and March levels were up 19.4% for the year. There was…

Home prices surged in February, according to the S&P/Case-Shiller index. The 20-City index rose 5.0% for the year, the fourth straight month to see an acceleration. Yearly price gains fell by more than half during 2014, a step that was supposed to restore some normalcy to the market and entice more buyers. But as inventory remains tight, prices have started…

Horton (DHI), the nation's largest homebuilder, said Wednesday that home sales in its second quarter, ended in March, grew 38% to $2.3 billion on 8,243 homes closed, up…
Stocks turned mixed near midday Monday amid a round of similarly mixed earnings reports, as well as economic reports both foreign and domestic.

The Nasdaq turned a 0.4% loss into a 0.3% gain. Biotechs and software issues outperformed. The S&P 500 pared a 0.5% deficit to 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today compared to the same time Friday.

Among highly rated stocks,Globant (GLOB) rallied nearly 4% to an all-time high and cleared a 35.10 buy point in heavy trading. About two hours into the session, the thin stock already matched its 50-day average volume.

Nike (NKE) climbed more than 1% to another new high after being upgraded to buy from hold at BB&T. It's now 12% past a 117.82 buy point. The athletic apparel and footwear giant was recently mentioned in the New Highs column.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) dropped 6% on news that it offered $2.2 billion to buy PMC-Sierra (PMCS). Its bid topped a $2 billion buyout offer by Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). Microsemi fell below a 37.51 buy point from a consolidation cleared Friday. PMC shares jumped 14%.

Valeant (VRX) slumped 6% despite beating views and raising guidance. Before the open, the Canadian drugmaker posted adjusted Q3 earnings of $2.74 a share, up from $2.11 a year ago. Sales grew 36%, the third straight period of acceleration, to almost $2.79 billion. It lifted its full-year sales forecast to $11 billion-$11.2 billion from $10.7 billion-$11.1 billion.

Profit is now expected at $11.67 to $11.87 a share, up from a prior outlook of $11.50 to $11.80. Last week, Valeant said it received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Massachusetts and New York, requesting information about its patient-assistance programs and drug-pricing decisions.

Horton's home sales gross margin also fell to 19.7% from 22.5% a…

Call it a spring comeback for housing? Existing-home sales leapt to the fastest rate in 18 months in March. The annual rate of 5.19 million beat expectations and marked the sixth-straight month of annual increases. In March, that was a 10.4% gain vs. 2014, the highest annual jump since August 2013. Prices spiked, rising 7.8% vs. a year ago, the…

As the peak earnings season kicks in this week, five homebuilder stocks will be among dozens of companies reporting their March quarters, days after reports showed disappointing housing starts for the month.If analyst estimates prove right, builder earnings for the quarter won't be much to write home about — unless you like to share uninspiring news.Earnings per share of the five reporting this week are seen falling from year-ago levels or showing little growth.Reston, Va.-based NVR (NVR) starts the parade on Tuesday, followed by No. 1 builder D.R. Horton (DHI) on Wednesday and PulteGroup (PHM), Meritage Homes (MTH) and small-cap M/I Homes (MHO) on Thursday.D.R. Horton's profit is expected to show zero growth, coming in the same as last year at 38 cents a share, according to the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. PulteGroup's profit is seen rising 5% to 20 cents, the best growth rate in the group.The rest are expected to show declines of 13% (Meritage) to between 22% and 25% (M/I Homes and NVR, respectively).Bad weather during the quarter may affect some of the builders. NVR, for example, has a majority of its communities in the hard-hit mid-Atlantic and Rust Belt, noted analyst Jay McCanless of Sterne Agee in a preview report on Friday.Of the five reporting, McCanless has buy ratings on only two — PulteGroup and Meritage. (He didn't report on M/I.) He expects Pulte's year-over-year orders in the quarter to be up 5%, above expectations for a little over 2%, and the average selling price to also come in above views, up 6.3% to $336,936.Meritage previously reported that January orders jumped 48% vs. a year earlier, which McCanless attributed to the addition of Legendary Homes in August and improving sales in the Southeast. He sees unit orders growing 16% for the full quarter, below views.McCanless noted that Fort Worth, Texas-based D.R. Horton is taking a "cautious approach" in Texas oil markets of Houston and Midland, which accounted for 6% of the builder's fiscal 2014 housing revenue.In D.R. Horton's December-ending first quarter, orders were higher than expected and its speculative home count grew by more than a third, McCanless noted.D.R. Horton is the highest rated stock in IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial industry group, with a Composite Rating of 96 out of a possible 99. Next highest is Lennar (LEN), which reported its February-ending first quarter last month. Lennar's earnings and revenue in the quarter topped views but gross margin fell, as expected, on higher costs.Homebuilder stocks fell in unison late last week after government data showed that March housing starts were up just 2% to an annualized rate of 926,000, missing views for 1.04 million. Starts were 2.5% lower than a year earlier.RELATED:Will Builders See Spring Home Sales Heat Up?
Stocks surrendered thin gains and slipped lower early Tuesday as investors contended with a rising dollar, sliding oil prices and mixed quarterly reports.
The Nasdaq was down 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 dipped 0.1% each.
Volume swept higher, with Nasdaq trade rising 23% and NYSE volume up 18% vs. action at the same time Monday.

The Nasdaq drifted up to just below its April 27 high in the stock market today before pulling back to a flat stance. Oil prices dived nearly 2%. Gold trimmed more than 1%. Comments from European Central Bank officials that offered a clearer view into more-aggressive-than-expected ECB bond buying sent the euro sharply lower vs. the dollar. Eurozone markets soared, with the CAC-40 in Paris up 1.8% in afternoon trade. China's mainland markets also posted a very positive session, buoyed by the government's market reform plan. The Deutsche X-Trackers Harvest CSI 300 Fund (ASHR) surged more than 4%.

April housing starts jumped to an annualized rate of 1.135 million, up 20% from the Commerce Department's revised March estimate. It was the highest mark in more than seven years and the biggest percent gain since 1991, the department said. Lennar (LEN), DR Horton (DHI), Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) all gained more than 1%.

Wal-Mart (WMT) gave the market wobbly knees, sliding more than 3% after both revenue and earnings missed analysts' first-quarter consensus projections. Sam's Club sales were weaker than expected, and currency exchange rates had some negative effect. Q2 earnings guidance was at the low end of analyst projections. The gap-down loss erased a three-session advance.

TJX (TJX) jumped nearly 3% in early trade, stepping to the front of the S&P 500 index. The owner of the Marshalls, Homegoods and TJ Maxx chains reported stronger-than-expected first-quarter sales and earnings. Management issued Q2 earnings guidance below analyst forecasts. The gap-up gain hoisted shares to within 3% of a 71.13 buy point in an eight-week flat base.

On the IBD 50 list, Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) muscled up more than 2% in very strong trade. The Woburn, Mass.-based chipmaker cleared a 102.87 buy point on Monday. It is still in buying range, not quite 3% above that pivot.

After the close, AutoDesk (ADSK), Etsy (ETSY), Analog Devices (ADI) and Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) are among the many companies scheduled to report quarterly results.Stocks surrendered thin gains and slipped lower early Tuesday as investors contended with a rising dollar, sliding oil prices and mixed quarterly reports.The Nasdaq was down 0.2%. Shares of PulteGroup (PHM) jumped Tuesday, leading homebuilder stocks higher, on reports that activist investor Elliott Management has taken a more than 4% stake in the company.Elliott informed PulteGroup that it had taken the position in the company, the homebuilder told Bloomberg in an emailed statement.A stake of more than 4% but less than 5% exempts Elliott from mandatory reporting requirements.The move comes after PulteGroup was criticized by co-founder and top shareholder Bill Pulte earlier this year. CEO Richard Dugas later announced his resignation, saying he planned to stay on in the position until next year.PulteGroup shares jumped 4.1% to 19.37 by the close in the stock market today. Among other top homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 2.1%, Lennar (LEN) and Toll Bros. (TOL) both climbed 2.5% and NVR (NVR) rose 0.4%.It wasn't immediately known what changes, if any, that Elliott will push for at the company, which has seen an exodus of top executives.

Professional builders, including the big publicly traded names like D.R. Horton (DHI), Lennar (LEN) and Pulte Group (PHM), don't go to Home Depot (HD) for the vast bulk of their supplies. They go to high-volume, high-service "pro segment" suppliers led by BMC Stock Holdings (BMCH), Builders FirstSource (BLDR) and Beacon Roofing (BECN). The largest pro segment supplier is Wisconsin-based ABC Supply, and…

Lennar's (LEN) shares popped early Tuesday before ending the session down, after the home builder reported strong quarterly profit and sales growth, as well as a backlog of orders that climbed 12% from a year earlier.Net earnings of $218.5 million in the company's fiscal second quarter were up from $183 million a year before. Adjusted earnings for the Miami-based company rose 20% in the fiscal second quarter to 95 cents a share, continuing a streak of better-than-expected earnings that goes back two years and beating analyst consensus by 9 cents a share.Revenue grew 15% to $2.746 billion amid low interest rates, constrained inventory and slow, steady economic growth, easily topping estimates of $2.573 billion. The builder delivered 6,724 new homes, up 12% from a year earlier. Gross profit margin on home sales eased to 23.1% from 23.8% in the second quarter of 2015 but improved sequentially by 40 basis points.The Commerce Department said Friday that housing starts slid 0.3% in May to an annual rate of 1.164 million units.New orders of 7,962 homes for Lennar were up 10% in units, and the dollar value for new orders was up 11% to $2.9 billion.Lennar shares rose more than 3% at one point but ultimately lost 1.1% to 46.14 on the stock market today.KB Home (KBH) was scheduled to report after the market close on Tuesday. Wall Street was targeting a 40% surge in EPS to 14 cents on a 20% hike in revenue to $747 million. KB Home recently announced a slew of new projects, including acquiring 199 home sites in Longmont, Colo., and buying 75 acres in northwest Bexar County, Texas, for 234 planned homes.KB Home shares rose 0.4% to 14.54. Among other large home builders, Pulte Group (PHM) was up a penny to 19.10, while NVR (NVR) lost 0.2% to 1,723.96. Toll Brothers (TOL) dipped 1.2% to 27.42.

Vacation home sales soared to a record high last year, according to a report that the National Association of Realtors (NAR) released Wednesday, as high-end households put some of their stock market and real estate earnings into second homes in spots that support a leisure lifestyle.
But the high-enders pulled back on investment purchases, which fell for the fourth straight year.
The median price paid was lower both for homes purchased with vacation-use plans and for homes intended as investment.

The NAR survey, which covers existing- and new-home transactions in 2014, shows that vacation home sales surged to an estimated 1.13 million last year, the highest amount since NAR began the survey in 2003. Vacation sales were up 57.4% from 717,000 in 2013.
The trend bodes well for homebuilders such as Toll Bros. (TOL), PulteGroup (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH), which build homes in various vacation and resort spots.
Investment-home sales in 2014 fell 7.4% to an estimated 1.02 million from 1.10 million in 2013. Owner-occupied purchases fell 12.8% to 3.23 million last year from 3.70 million in 2013.
NAR Chief Economist Lawrence Yun noted that vacation home sales in 2014 nearly doubled the combined total of the previous two years.

"Affluent households have greatly benefited from strong growth in the stock market in recent years, and the steady rise in home prices has likely given them reassurance that real estate remains an attractive long-term investment," he said in a statement. "Furthermore, last year's impressive increase also reflects long-term growth in the numbers of baby boomers moving closer to retirement and buying second homes to convert into their primary home in a few years."
Vacation-home sales accounted for 21% of all transactions in 2014, their highest market share since the survey was first conducted.

"Despite strong rental demand in many markets, investment property sales have declined four consecutive years to their lowest share since 2010 as rising home prices and fewer distressed properties coming onto the market have further reduced the number of bargains available to turn into profitable rentals," said Yun.
The portion of investment sales fell to 19% in 2014 from 20% in 2013, the report said. Owner-occupied purchases declined to 60% last year from 67% in 2013.
The median vacation home price was $150,000 in 2014, down 11.1% from $168,700 in 2013. The median investment-home sales price was $125,000, down 3.8% from $130,000 a year earlier.

"The decrease in vacation and investment sales prices is likely due to the increase in vacation and investment buyers purchasing condos and townhouses, which contributed to a decline in the median size of 200 square feet for both," noted Yun.Vacation home sales soared to a record high last year, according to a report that the National Association of Realtors (NAR) released Wednesday, as high-end households put some of their stock market and real estate earnings into second homes in spots that support a leisure lifestyle.But the high-enders pulled back on investment purchases, which fell for the fourth straight year.The median price paid was lower both for homes purchased with vacation-use plans and for homes intended as investment.The NAR survey, which covers existing- and new-home transactions in 2014, shows that vacation home sales surged to an estimated 1.13 million last year, the highest amount since NAR began the survey in 2003. Home price appreciation has outpaced wage growth by a wide margin during the housing market recovery, a trend that's kept many traditional buyers out of the market, according to a report from RealtyTrac released Thursday morning. Home price appreciation has grown faster than wages in 76% of U.S. housing markets during the housing market recovery of the past two years,…

Annual home-price appreciation slowed in 65% of major U.S. metro areas in February, according to a report by RealtyTrac out Friday morning. Sixty of the 92 metro areas analyzed with a population of 500,000 or more saw annual home price appreciation decline in February compared with annual home price appreciation a year ago, the report said. U.S. stocks showed hesitation Wednesday after the previous session's strong price gains. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today dropped vs. Tuesday's already below-average pace.

Blue chips were mostly down. Only a handful of stocks in the Dow rose and those in tiny steps. On the downside, Chevron (CVX) carved off 1% in slow turnover as West Texas intermediate crude oil fell 3.5%. Chevron, an integrated oil company, has rebounded about 30% off its late August low but remains about 33% off its July 2014 high.

An integrated oil company is involved in many facets of the business: exploration, production, refining and distribution. From late June 2014, when crude oil began its fast price slide, the price of oil is now down 64%; U.S. explorers, down 63%; integrated, down 41%; and refiners, down 21%.

In the IBD 50 — a list of the best stocks in fundamentals and technicals — mortgage software provider Ellie Mae (ELLI) took the hardest hit, dropping more than 2%. But volume was about 20% below average.
Housing-related stocks got some bad news as November pending home sales dropped unexpectedly.

However, homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI), a Leaderboard stock, shrugged the news off. Pending home sales in January were a sigh of relief for a real estate market that's seen a lot of false starts in the aftermath of the housing bubble and recession.The National Association of Realtors' index rose 1.7%, enough to push it to an 18-month high. January also marked the fifth-straight month of annual increases, each one stronger than the last. In January, that was 8.4% above year-ago levels. All-cash purchases are easing and the job market is strengthening, making for a healthier market overall, NAR said.While real estate is still a local story, only one region, the Midwest, saw a monthly decline in January, and all had annual increases. The South remains the strongest market and also had the biggest monthly jump, 3.2%. The Northeast remains the weakest, but eked out a 0.1% gain in January.Pending home sales reflect contract signings for existing home sales. The index offers an indication of actual existing home sales that close in February or March.Shares of homebuildersToll Bros. (TOL), Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH), D.R. Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM) rose modestly in Friday afternoon trading.

New home sales surprised to the upside in January, a change of pace for the beleaguered housing market. The annual rate of sales declined, but only by 1,000, to 481,000, and December sales were revised up by the same amount. Forecasts had called for a rate of 471,000 in January. The month's sales were 5.3% stronger than year-ago levels, and…

The S&P/Case-Shiller 20-city home price index rose more than expected in December, with the annual gain picking up slightly, suggesting the deceleration trend of the past year is over.Homes appreciated 4.5% in December vs. a year earlier, up from 4.3% in November and forecasts for the same. It was the first acceleration since November 2013. Fast-rising home prices a year ago helped chill home sales. With price gains more moderate, interest rates low and job and wage growth picking up, affordability should also be improving.Still, housing remains uneven."While prices and sales of existing homes are close to normal, construction and new home sales remain weak," David Blitzer, chairman of the index committee at S&P Dow Jones Indices, said in a statement.But there was good news from homebuilders Tuesday. Luxury builder Toll Bros. (TOL) reported better-than-expected earnings, on strong pricing and profit margins. Toll shares rose 4.5% in midday trading on the stock market today, breaking out to an 11-month high. Meritage Homes (MTH), which reported a 48% spike in January home orders, advanced 6% intraday, setting a 10-month intraday best.Among other homebuilder stocks, Lennar (LEN) rose 2.6% intraday, D.R. Horton (DHI) 1.1% and PulteGroup (PHM) 2.1%.

Ryland Group (RYL) showed the biggest gain on the stock market this week among the several homebuilders that reported quarterly results since Monday. In a week of mixed reports, Ryland was up more than 9% for the week as of mid-afternoon Friday. Most of the gain came on Thursday after Q4 earnings and profit beat analyst views and gross profit…

Existing-home sales ran at an annual rate of 5.04 million in December, just missing expectations of 5.05 million, but still an improvement over November. Prices rose 1.1% as inventory sank 11%. At the current pace of sales, there are 4.4 months' worth of homes on the market, down from 5.1 months in November and well below the 6 months considered…

In another sign that the housing recovery is moving on track, the share of underwater homeowners sank to a low point at the end of the fourth quarter, according to a report released Thursday by housing data and analytics provider RealtyTrac.

At the end of the year, there were 7.052 million U.S. residential properties seriously underwater — where the combined loan amount secured by the property is at least 25% higher than the property's estimated market value — representing 13% of all properties with a mortgage.

The number and share of seriously underwater homeowners at the end of 2014 were both at their lowest levels since RealtyTrac began tracking trends in home equity, in the first quarter of 2012, and they are down from a peak of 12.8 million seriously underwater homeowners — 29% of all owners with a mortgage — in the second quarter of 2012.
The Power Of Prices

"Median home prices nationwide bottomed out in March 2012 and since then have increased 35%, lifting 5.8 million homeowners out of seriously underwater territory," said Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac, in a statement.

"While the remaining seriously underwater properties continue to be a millstone around the neck of some local markets," he added, "the growing number of equity-rich homeowners should help counteract the downward pull of negative equity in many markets, empowering those housing markets — and by extension their local economies — to 'walk on water' in 2015."

Equity-rich properties, those with at least 50% positive equity, increased to 11.25 million at the end of 2014, representing 20% of all properties with a mortgage — up from 9.10 million equity-rich properties at the end of 2013.

As the number of underwater properties decreases and the number of equity-rich properties rises, more owners will have the ability to meet underwriting standards and finance the purchase of new homes. With a nice equity cushion in their dwellings, combined with a rising home value, owners may be more receptive to sell and move up to bigger homes.
So a lesser number of underwater homeowners and a greater number of equity-rich homeowners could benefit homebuilders such as Lennar (LEN), Toll Bros. (TOL) and PulteGroup (PHM).

"With price escalation returning home values to near peak levels, homeowners who have positive equity have options before they face foreclosure," said Chris Pollinger, senior vice president of sales at First Team Real Estate, in the RealtyTrac report. Pollinger is based in Southern California; RealtyTrac notes that 6% of residential properties with a mortgage in the Los Angeles metro area were seriously underwater at the end of 2014, compared with 32% that were equity-rich.

Other major markets where the share of seriously underwater properties was below 10% at the end of 2014 included San Jose, Calif., at 2%; Denver at 4%; Minneapolis, Boston and San Francisco at 5%; Pittsburgh at 6%; Houston and Dallas at 8%; and Seattle at 9%.In another sign that the housing recovery is moving on track, the share of underwater homeowners sank to a low point at the end of the fourth quarter, according to a report released Thursday by housing data and analytics provider RealtyTrac.At the end of the year, there were 7.052 million U.S. residential properties seriously underwater — where the combined loan amount secured by the property is at least 25% higher than the property's estimated market value — representing 13% of all properties with a mortgage.The number and share of seriously underwater homeowners at the end of 2014 were both at their lowest levels since RealtyTrac began tracking trends in home equity, in the first quarter of 2012, and they are down from a peak of 12.8 million seriously underwater homeowners — 29% of all owners with a mortgage — in the second quarter of 2012.The Power Of Prices"Median home prices nationwide bottomed out in March 2012 and since then have increased 35%, lifting 5.8 million homeowners out of seriously underwater territory," said Daren Blomquist, vice president at RealtyTrac, in a statement."While the remaining seriously underwater properties continue to be a millstone around the neck of some local markets," he added, "the growing number of equity-rich homeowners should help counteract the downward pull of negative equity in many markets, empowering those housing markets — and by extension their local economies — to 'walk on water' in 2015."Equity-rich properties, those with at least 50% positive equity, increased to 11.25 million at the end of 2014, representing 20% of all properties with a mortgage — up from 9.10 million equity-rich properties at the end of 2013.As the number of underwater properties decreases and the number of equity-rich properties rises, more owners will have the ability to meet underwriting standards and finance the purchase of new homes. D.R. Horton calmed fears Monday about shrinking homebuilder profit margins by maintaining its outlook for this year — less than two weeks after two other top builders set off panic by warning theirs will continue to narrow. The Fort Worth, Texas-based company said it continues to see its average home sales gross margin at around 20% for this year, though…

Homebuilders were relatively upbeat in January, the National Association of Home Builders said, considering how little buyer traffic they're seeing. The NAHB's overall sentiment index dipped 1 point from an upwardly-revised 58 in Dec. That's still solidly in expansion territory and well above the post-recession average of about 33. The current conditions gauge at 62 and the one measuring the…

Data disclosed last week indicated the housing recovery is on track. That may lift homebuilders such as D.R. Horton (DHI), which leads off a busy week in which five homebuilders are slated to report quarterly performance.Homebuilders are trying to rebound after earnings and revenue growth weakened in the back half of 2014 amid market uncertainty.D.R. Horton, which bills itself as "America's Builder" and is the largest in the group by annual revenue, will release first-quarter financial results Monday before the market opens.The consensus of analysts is for a 2-cent drop in earnings per share to 34 cents. Investors hope Horton can reverse that to a beat after missing analysts' EPS estimates the prior two quarters.Revenue is projected to rise 27.2% to $2.075 billion.D.R. Horton stock is bouncing back from a failed breakout with a 26.04 buy point. It's trading below its 50-day but finding support at its 200-day line. Horton closed down 2.5% Friday to 23.10.PulteGroup (PHM) is set to announce Q4 earnings Thursday before the market opens.Wall Street expects the builder of single-family homes, condos, townhouses and duplexes to report a 17-cent drop in EPS to 40 cents. Investors will be looking for a repeat of the prior quarter's results when Pulte reported better than expected EPS.Revenue is projected to grow 6.5% to $1.76 billion.Pulte shares moved sideways for most of 2014, trading in a narrow range. Like Horton, it tried to break out early this year but retreated and was trading back in the range Friday. It closed Friday off 1% to 20.69.Smaller peers MDC Holdings (MDC), Ryland (RYL) and Beazer Homes (BZH) will also report results, opening a window onto housing prospects this year.MDC is scheduled to release Q4 earnings Wednesday. Ryland will announce Q4 Thursday, and Beazer is on tap to release fiscal Q1 earnings Friday.Bullish signs are popping up for homebuilders. The Census Bureau said last week that December housing starts beat estimates, rising 4.4% to an annualized 1.098 million units and lifting 2014 to the strongest overall year since 2007.Single-family home permits rose 4.5% in December to an annual rate of 667,000, the strongest monthly gain of 2014.In another sign the housing recovery is on track, the share of homeowners whose loans are underwater fell to the lowest point since the number peaked in the second quarter 2012, according to housing market tracker RealtyTrac.However, Lennar (LEN), which builds single-family homes in 17 states, on Jan. 15 reported higher earnings per share, but revenue growth fell short of estimates. And Lennar said it expects lower profit margins this year amid rising costs.KB Home (KBH) also reported a revenue gain on Jan. 13, but EPS fell 9.7% and was half what Wall Street expected.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar.

The stock market closed with a flurry of buying, as most broad indexes added more than 1%. The Nasdaq led with a 1.5% gain as biotech, generic-drug and computer hardware stocks gave strong performances.
The S&P 500 rallied 1.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.9%. All indexes closed near session highs.
Small caps outperformed: The Russell 2000 was up 2% at the closing bell.

Volume was lower on the NYSE and slightly higher on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Breadth was impressive, with winning stocks leading losers by nearly 4-to-1 on the Nasdaq and by 9-to-2 on the NYSE.
Earnings reports continued to influence the stock market today.

Visa (V) gapped down in heavy volume, closing below the 77.02 buy point the stock had broken out from two weeks ago. The credit card company missed profit estimates and confirmed it is acquiring Visa Europe.
After the close, Fitbit (FIT) shares fell moderately after the company announced results for Q3.

Operating earnings per share of 13 cents were above the consensus estimate of 10 cents, and Fitbit also raised guidance. But it also announced a follow-on offering of 7 million shares from the company, and certain stockholders are seeking to sell 14 million shares.

In its earnings announcement, Fitbit said that lock-up restrictions for Fitbit's employees and consultants will be lifted Wednesday. Some 2.3 million shares, which represent up to 10% of Fitbit common stock, options, and restricted stock held by insiders, will hit the market. Other lock-up restrictions are set to end Dec. 14.
Among other leading stocks, LGI Homes (LGIH) rallied back above its 50-day moving average in average volume. The stock is now in a secondary buy area, thanks to the support that has emerged.
On Tuesday, earnings reports are due from Tesla Motors (TSLA), Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH) and Activision Blizzard (ATVI).
At 10 a.m. ET Tuesday, the latest reading on factory orders is released. Automakers will announce sales for the month of October.

Stocks remained vastly lower late Thursday, but have trimmed some losses. The Nasdaq has cut an early loss of about 2% to 1.7%, while the S&P 500 shaved a 1.2% deficit to 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.8%. Volume ran sharply higher across the board.
Gray Television (GTN) came off its session low, but was still down 12%. Intraday, the stock slumped more than 8% below a 16.77 buy point from a flat base, marking a sell signal.
AMC Networks (AMCX) trimmed its early 14% deficit to about 9%, but the damage had also been done. Earlier, it triggered the 8% sell rule from an 80.08 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.
Media stocks were hammered in stock market today amid weak quarterly sales from Viacom (VIAB). Shares of the diversified media firm were off their session lows, but still down almost 14%.

On the upside, FleetCor Technologies (FLT) bucked market weakness and was up 3%. It had jumped up as much as 6% following late-Wednesday's better-than-expected earnings. Susquehanna upgraded shares to positive from neutral Thursday. FleetCor is a flat base with a 165.77 buy point.

Arista Networks (ANET), BitAuto (BITA), Fleetmatics (FLTX), Jack In The Box (JACK), Middleby (MIDD), Monster Beverage (MNST), Nvidia (NVDA) and Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) are a few notable companies reporting earnings after the close.Stocks remained vastly lower late Thursday, but have trimmed some losses. In the latest in a flurry of good news for the housing market, foreclosure starts slid close to a decade low in July as banks cleared out old distressed properties while tightened lending standards have helped curb the number of new ones coming in the market. A total of 45,381 U.S. properties started the foreclosure process for the first time…

The fourth-quarter earnings results season is just getting into full gear this week. Already, big selling by institutional investors is trampling recent gains by homebuilder stocks. Tuesday's 2.3% drop in IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial industry subgroup spoiled what looked to be a solid start in 2015. KB Home (KBH) triggered the selling avalanche. It reported a second straight decline in adjusted quarterly…

KB Home (KBH) shares saw a huge reversal on the stock market Tuesday — and led a decline in the homebuilding industry group — after its CEO warned about a long-term trend that could negatively impact earnings. During KB Home's earnings conference call, CEO Jeffrey Mezger warned that the homebuilding profit margin drop it saw last quarter is the start…

Stocks jumped Tuesday, with the Nasdaq posting its biggest gain in nearly three months, after a big increase in existing-home sales suggested that the economy may be able to weather higher interest rates.The Nasdaq rallied 2%, the S&P 500 rose 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2%. All three indexes climbed back above their converging 200-day and 50-day moving averages, a bullish indicator for the health of the overall market. In another good sign, volume rose across the board compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Machinery, auto parts and consumer-related stocks paced the gains in the stock market today, while miners underperformed as gold prices dropped.Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 3% and cleared a 98.10 buy point. Its relative strength line is hitting new highs, which is a bullish indicator, but volume on the breakout was weak.How does Adobe Systems stack up against its rivals in the desktop software industry? Find out at IBD's Stock Checkup.Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) rose 2%, climbing above a 66.34 buy point of a cup-with-handle base in heavy volume.Homebuilders fared well after sales of existing homes soared 16% in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 619,000 units, the highest since January 2008.Pulte Group (PHM) rose 5%, retaking its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. Lennar (LEN) rose nearly 4% and D.R. Horton (DHI) added more than 4%, retaking its 50-day moving average as it works on a cup-with handle base with a 32.61 buy point.All but one of the IBD 50 stocks rose, led by NetEase (NTES), which jumped 6%. The Chinese online gaming stock is climbing the right side of a cup-type base with a possible 186.55 buy point.Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) was the only decliner, ending down a fraction after erasing an early gain of about 1%. The pet food maker is having trouble clearing a 26.08 cup-with-handle buy point.

Stocks jumped Tuesday, with the Nasdaq posting its biggest gain in nearly three months, after strong new-home sales suggested that the economy may be able to withstand higher interest rates.The Nasdaq rallied 2%, the S&P 500 rose 1.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2%. The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq are now both above their 200-day and 50-day moving averages, a bullish indicator for the health of the overall market. In another good sign, volume rose across the board compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) was up 9% in post-session trading after announcing that it will spin off its enterprise services unit and merge it with Computer Sciences (CSC), which soared 23% after hours."The 'spin-merger' of HPE's Enterprise Services unit with CSC is the right next step for HPE and our customers," Meg Whitman, CEO of Hewlett Packard Enterprise, said in a statement. HP Enterprise is itself a spinoff from the former Hewlett-Packard. The announcement came as both companies prepared to release quarterly earnings late Tuesday.Meanwhile, machinery, auto parts and consumer-related stocks paced the gains in the stock market today, while miners underperformed as gold prices dropped.Adobe Systems (ADBE) rose 3% and cleared a 98.10 buy point. Its relative strength line is hitting new highs, which is a bullish indicator, but volume on the breakout was weak.How does Adobe Systems stack up against its rivals in the desktop software industry? Lennar (LEN) rose nearly 4% and D.R. Horton (DHI) added more than 4%, retaking its 50-day moving average as it works on a cup-with handle base with a 32.61 buy point.All but one of the IBD 50 stocks rose, led by NetEase (NTES), which jumped 6%. The Chinese online gaming stock is climbing the right side of a cup-type base with a possible 186.55 buy point.Blue Buffalo Pet Products (BUFF) was the only decliner, ending down a fraction after erasing an early gain of about 1%. The pet food maker is having trouble clearing a 26.08 cup-with-handle buy point.Guess (GES), Costco (COST), Williams-Sonoma (WSM) and PVH (PVH) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Stock futures narrowed their early gains on the approach to Friday's preholiday weekend session, as investors tussled with earnings and merger news and revised GDP data.Nasdaq 100 futures pared gains to less than 0.2% above fair value. Dow industrials and S&P 500 futures held gains of less than 0.1% each. Small caps were a weak spot, with Russell 2000 futures slipping in and out of fractional losses.The stock market today looks to close out what has so far been a week of improvement for the market. The Nasdaq heads into the session up 2.8% and back above its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 opens with a 1.8% gain for the week. It is the best performance since the week ended April 1 and a second straight advance for both indexes.Apple (AAPL) slipped more than 1% early Friday, weighing on the Dow and the Nasdaq 100. Western Digital (WDC) dropped 1.4%, also dragging on the Nasdaq after lowering its fiscal Q4 EPS and revenue guidance based on its acquisition of SanDisk.Veeva Systems (VEEV) swept up 9% in premarket action. The medical software maker reported late Thursday that both earnings and revenue cleared analyst estimates, and management lifted second-quarter and full-year revenue guidance above forecasts. Shares ended Thursday 6% above a 28.05 buy point from a cup-with-handle base after a low-volume breakout in mid-May.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) also scrambled 9% higher after reporting its first-quarter results late Thursday. The Bolingbrook, Ill.-based chain reported earnings up 39% on a 24% jump in revenue. Both easily cleared consensus targets. Comparable-store sales surged 15%.Management's second-quarter earnings guidance was below expectations, but revenue guidance was better than expected. Ulta shares have been nibbling away at new highs and ended Thursday extended 13% past a 188.58 buy point.Outside the IBD 50, Big Lots (BIG) muscled out a 13% premarket advance. Its first-quarter earnings blew past expectations, and revenue growth topped by a narrow margin. The stock's premarket move implies an open back above a 46.23 buy point, which the stock had initially topped in April.GameStop (GME) ripped 6% lower after reporting its Q2 results after Thursday’s close.In some random moves, not related to earnings, homebuilder Pulte Group (PHM) powered up nearly 6% in premarket trade. Liberty Global (LBTYK) popped 5%Heavy equipment maker Terex (TEX) plunged 18% lower after China's Zoomlion called off its $3.4 billion acquisition bid.Embattled drug maker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) scaled up 6% after announcing it had rejected a joint takeover bid from Japan's Takeda Pharmaceuticals and private equity outfit TPG.The Commerce Department revised its first-quarter GDP growth estimate slightly higher, to 0.8%, vs. and initial estimate of a 0.5% increase. It eased its inflation estimate slightly, pulling the GDP Price Index back to a 0.6%, from an original 0.7% increase.The University of Michigan serves up its final reading on Consumer Sentiment for May. Baker Hughes' (BHI) weekly rig count is due out at 1 p.m. ET, and Janet Yellen joins a discussion about interest rates at Harvard University at 1:15 p.m.Crude oil trimmed early losses to less than 1%, putting West Texas Intermediate just above $49 a barrel and up about 6% for the week. Gold was essentially flat at $1,220 an ounce, 4% below last Friday's settlement. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro, down vs. the yen, and bonds held steady.

Sales of new homes hit a four-year high last month, and luxury homebuilder Toll Bros. (TOL) said Tuesday the foundation for continued growth is in place, though questions remain about millennials' future buying habits.The Commerce Department said April new-home sales skyrocketed 16.6% to an annualized rate of 619,000, the highest since January 2008. Wall Street was looking for a small increase to 523,000 units."We continue to believe the drivers are in place to sustain the current housing market's slow but steady growth," Toll Bros. Chairman Robert Toll said in a statement."Interest rates remain low, the job picture continues to improve, home equity values are rising, supply remains constrained and the industry is still not building enough homes to meet the demand that current demographics imply are needed."Toll Bros. shares closed up 8.7% in the stock market today, gapping above their 50-day average. Among other homebuilders, NVR (NVR) rose 3%. D.R. Horton (DHI) added 4.2%, Lennar (LEN) rose 3.9%, and PulteGroup (PHM) climbed 5.1%.Toll Bros., which sells to more affluent buyers, said adjusted fiscal second-quarter earnings climbed 39% to 51 cents a share, beating analyst estimates by 6 cents. Revenue grew 31% to $1.12 billion, well above analyst views for $1.04 billion.The homebuilder expects full-year revenue of $4.76 billion-$5.36 billion, with the midpoint of the range above views for $5.01 billion. Toll Bros. also expects to deliver 5,800-6,300 new homes for the year, with an average value of $820,000-$850,000.Meanwhile, the Commerce Department said the average home price climbed 6% to $379,800.Stifel Chief Economist Lindsey Piegza said the price increase may be too big for some consumers to swallow. "If the price of new homes continues to go up, it will make it more difficult for the average potential homeowner to buy."Piegza noted sales are still well below pre-recession highs. In April 2005, there were 1.26 million new homes sold, nearly double the figure this year, according to Commerce figures.Other analysts see strong results ahead."Today's numbers were eye-popping growth," said Lawrence Yun, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. "There is still plenty of momentum to go forward."But new questions arose about whether millennials will buy homes at the same rate as earlier generations did. Piegza said they prefer to rent and may stay out of the home-buying market in the near term.And a new Pew Research Center study out Tuesday found that Americans 18 to 34 years old in 2014 were more likely to be live with their parents than in their own household with a spouse or partner. Pew said that is the first time that's happened in the modern era.But Robert Toll remained upbeat about the key demographic group, saying on a conference call that “as millennials mature, studies indicate their appetite for housing is consistent with past generations.”Meanwhile, paint and coatings company Valspar (VAL), which is being bought by Sherwin-Williams (SHW) for $11.3 billion, also said Tuesday that adjusted fiscal Q2 earnings rose 9.9% to $1.22 a share, 4 cents below forecasts. Revenue slid 2.1% to $1.056 billion, lighter than the expected $1.122 billion.
The data show that a bunch of your neighbors may have spent their New Year's downtime plotting how to save money on their house. Now's an even better time to resolve to do the same, and here's why.
Applications to refinance home mortgages vaulted 66% in the week that ended last Friday, Jan. 9, as mortgage rates were on their way down to lows not seen since mid-2013.

After ending 2014 at 3.87%, the average interest rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 3.73% in the week that ended Thursday, Jan. 8, right when applications were surging. And in the week ended Thursday, Jan. 15, rates fell even further — to 3.66%.

The last time you could get that good a deal on your mortgage was the week of May 23, 2013, when the going average was 3.59%, according to Freddie Mac's (FMCC) survey. About four years ago, in early 2011, the average was around 5%.
Rates dropped, economists note, as the price of oil sank and as long-term Treasury yields fell in a flight to safety tied to world economic concerns.
Whether it makes sense to refinance now depends on many factors, including how long you plan to stay in your home and how long it will take to pay off the closing costs on a new loan.

Plenty of people started out the year as homebuyers, not just as refinancers. In the Mortgage Bankers Association's analysis, a purchase-mortgage applications index rose 24% for the week that ended Jan. 9.

Nevertheless, builder Lennar's (LEN) stock sank Thursday as it gave quarterly results and forecast less pricing power in 2015. That could be good for new-home buyers, however. KB Home (KBH) also dropped after earlier in the week reporting quarterly results that included a warning about its profit margins. Other builders falling in the market Thursday included D.R. Horton (DHI) and PulteGroup (PHM).

Lennar added to the homebuilding gloom Thursday as it became the latest company to warn on lower margins amid rising costs and bigger promotions — despite other trends that point to more housing demand. The Miami-based builder sees gross margins on home sales dipping this year to 24% from 25.4% in 2014. The warning comes even as Lennar (LEN) remains…

If location (location, location) is indeed the key to success in real estate, then homebuilders with operations in Seattle, Salt Lake City, Nashville, Tenn., Atlanta and Boston should see good times in 2015.

Those are among cities cited by economists as having the best housing market gains this year based on job growth, housing demand, home price strength and other factors. Others frequently mentioned are Dallas, Denver, San Jose, Calif., Charlotte, N.C., and Raleigh, N.C.

Although recent quarterly reports from builders have disappointed investors, economists are generally upbeat about the 2015 housing market in most sections of the U.S. They point to improving economic and employment data.

"Housing is driven by the local job market, and job gains are accelerating," said Lawrence Yun, chief economist with the National Association of Realtors. "It's positive news for all parts of the country."
Cities That Work
The news is particularly positive for cities, many in the South, that have seen rapid job gains across several different industries. Yun points to Atlanta, Nashville, Charlotte and Charleston, S.C.
"We've seen many manufacturing and financial services companies moving operations into Southern states," he told IBD.

As an example, Yun cites the news last week that Daimler AG's (DDAIF) Mercedes-Benz will move its U.S. division headquarters from New Jersey to the Atlanta metro area. In the summer Boeing (BA) said that the largest of its 787 Dreamliners, the 787-10 launched in 2013, will be assembled in North Charleston, S.C.
Other metro areas with strong job markets are Seattle, San Francisco and San Jose, Yun says.
"The weak point will be the Northeast from New York to Maine," he said. "That region will be sluggish in terms of home price recovery, with the exception of Boston."

Trulia Chief Economist Jed Kolko has a more cautious take on housing in general. In a report emailed to IBD, Kolko said "barriers remain to homeownership." These include difficulty saving for a down payment and poor credit.
Not having a stable job "has become considerably less of an obstacle," Kolko said, but affordability "has become a bigger obstacle."

Kolko noted that certain markets have the right combination of fundamentals, for both buyers and renters, to enjoy strong housing growth in 2015. He cites Boston, Nashville, Salt Lake City, Seattle, Raleigh, Dallas, New York, San Diego, Fresno, Calif., and Middlesex County, Mass.
Two important demographic groups — baby boomers and millennials — will also drive housing gains in certain markets, experts say.

Cities poised to benefit from an influx of boomers include Denver, Raleigh, Orlando, Fla., and Tucson, Ariz., the NAR reports. Top markets for millennial homebuyers include Austin, Dallas, Denver, Minneapolis, New Orleans, Seattle and Salt Lake City.
Several homebuilders stand to gain from hot housing markets in these and other cities.
D.R. Horton (DHI), for example, lists 11 communities in the Seattle area and 13 in greater Salt Lake City. D.R. Horton also has a big stake in Dallas, along with PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN).

Beazer Homes USA (BZH) has several communities in Southeastern metro areas, such as Atlanta, Nashville and Raleigh-Durham. Builders with a big stake in California's Silicon Valley include Tri Pointe Homes (TPH) and Ryland Group (RYL).

Two metrics that economists look at to gauge an area's housing market strength are median home price growth and inventory. A rise in home prices indicates an increase in demand, while a drop in inventory shows that available homes are selling.
Sweet Spots For Growth

A Dec. 23 NAR report showed a handful of big U.S. metro areas seeing double-digit growth in median home prices as well as high single-digit to double-digit drops in inventory in November, the last month for which data are available. Cities on the list included Chicago, Houston, Dallas, Charlotte and Nashville.
These big metro areas saw double-digit price increases but also flat or growing inventory: San Jose, Denver, Atlanta and Austin, Texas.
While those metrics are a "good indicator of the current housing situation," Yun said they are not necessarily a forecast of future growth.
"One thing we do know is that these markets are not afraid of raising prices," he said. "But future growth will all be tied to job gains and whether local markets will sustain solid job gains."
The ability to sustain solid job gains has become a recent worry in Texas, where declining oil and gas prices are expected to have a negative impact on the state's job growth and housing markets.

In a recent report, Sterne Agee analyst Jay McCanless lowered his fourth-quarter EPS estimates forKB Home (KBH) given its exposure to states with large oil plays, including Texas, New Mexico and Colorado.
KB stock has plummeted 25% since the builder on Tuesday reported Q4 earnings well below consensus estimates and warned that softer demand will hurt its margins.
Thursday, Lennar stock fell 7% as that company also warned, in its Q4 report, that margins will soften.

In a recent report on Lennar, McCanless said he is "apprehensive about the Houston market based on recent oil price declines as well as recent economic commentary predicting slower job growth in that market." A similar concern was raised in a research note he issued on Beazer and "the potential effects lower oil prices might have on Texas buyer sentiment."

The NAR's Yun shares those concerns. Based on his analysis of the oil market, he expects oil prices to "remain low" the next two or three years. This will likely have an impact on Texas jobs and housing.

"I don't see job cuts necessarily, but we won't see the same level of job creation in Texas," Yun said.If location (location, location) is indeed the key to success in real estate, then homebuilders with operations in Seattle, Salt Lake City, Nashville, Tenn., Atlanta and Boston should see good times in 2015.Those are among cities cited by economists as having the best housing market gains this year based on job growth, housing demand, home price strength and other factors.
